message.title: Message
message.content1: Morilab is a research lab that creates useful systems in the medical field based on high-dimensional image analysis from 2D to 4D. By using the technology that computers understand the human body, we aim to revolutionize diagnosis and treatment, and to challenge new industrial applications and visualizations.
message.content2: We respect autonomy and work together with partners around the world to create a better future.

theme1.title: Image Recognition, Understanding, and Computer Vision
theme1.description: Use PC to analyze medical images and connect to cancer detection and density structure analysis

message.title: Message from Morilab
message.message: Morilab is a research lab that creates useful systems in the medical field based on high-dimensional image analysis from 2D to 4D. By using the technology that computers understand the human body, we aim to revolutionize diagnosis and treatment, and to challenge new industrial applications and visualizations.

bachelor.title: Undergraduate
bachelor.description: Please apply to Morilab in the research room assignment in the third year of the Computer Science Department of the Nagoya University Faculty of Engineering and Information and Communication Engineering Department.

master.title: Graduate Student (Master)
master.description: Please take the entrance exam to the Doctoral Course of the Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, Nagoya University. Please also apply to Morilab.

doctor.title: Graduate Student (Doctor)
doctor.description: Please take the entrance exam to the Doctoral Course of the Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, Nagoya University. Please also apply to Morilab.

path.title: Example of Graduates' Paths (Name and Year in no particular order. Includes graduates from the old Morilab.)
path.description: Graduates are active in a wide range of industries such as automobiles, electrical equipment, communication, and transportation. Of course, there are also graduates who are active in companies that are related to medical image processing.
path.example: Example: DENSO, Canon, Toyota, Brother, Ricoh, Toyota Auto, Suzuki, Fujitsu, NTT, Fuji Film, Omron, Sony, IBM, Panasonic, etc.

imageRecognition.title: 1. Image Recognition, Understanding, and Computer Vision
imageRecognition.content: We conduct research on high-precision real-time image analysis technologies that contribute to medical and industrial applications. Our work centers on 3D grayscale image recognition and 3D binary image processing, including the extraction of fine linear structures, acceleration of image algorithms using GPUs, multi-camera medical calibration, and integration with sensor information. These technologies are applied to surgical navigation and diagnostic support, revolutionizing clinical workflows. Furthermore, we are developing visualization methods for high-dimensional data, aiming to deliver results in forms that can be readily applied in practice.

imageGeneration.title: 2. Image Generation, Visualization Technology (Computer Graphics)
imageGeneration.content: In high-speed, high-resolution volume rendering, we have developed a fast software-based approach that utilizes only PC multimedia instructions to render dozens of frames per second, which has been applied to virtual endoscopy. Furthermore, we have implemented visualization methods with image deformation to compensate for organ motion and measurement errors, enabling applications in real-time surgical support and dynamic organ analysis.
imageGeneration.imageDescription: Visualization of a large-scale turbulent flow obtained by a supercomputer

3dPrinter.title: Use of 3D-printed human organ models
3dPrinter.content: In the medical field, the utilization of 3D printing has been expanding in various directions, including implant fabrication, diagnostic support, surgical simulation, surgical navigation, informed consent, and medical and nursing education.
3dPrinter.imageDescription1: Kidney model created by shape exposure method
3dPrinter.imageDescription2: Model of microvascular structure created by shape exposure method

virtualEndoscope.title: Virtual Endoscopy
virtualEndoscope.content: This is a technique that generates images from CT and MR scans as if they were observed through an endoscope. We have been conducting continuous research on this since 1993 and published the first paper on virtual endoscopy, which enables real-time interactive exploration.
virtualEndoscope.imageDescription1: Virtual endoscopy system at the time
virtualEndoscope.imageDescription2: Current virtual endoscopy system. If you would like to evaluate, please contact us by email.

medicalImageRecognition.title: Medical Image Recognition
medicalImageRecognition.content: The target domains are airways, abdominal organs, and lymph nodes. For the airways, we are conducting research on extracting the airway region from CT images (segmentation) and automatically assigning anatomical names to each branch of the extracted airway region. For abdominal organs, we are conducting research on automatically detecting various organs from abdominal CT images at the same time. For lymph nodes, we are conducting research on detecting lymph nodes from CT images.
medicalImageRecognition.imageDescription2: Result of assigning anatomical names to each branch of the extracted airway region

cad.title: Computer-aided diagnosis and automatic diagnosis (CAD)
cad.content: We are conducting research on systems that support the diagnosis of lung cancer, emphysema, and colorectal polyps.

surgerySimulation.title: Surgery Simulation
surgerySimulation.content: In laparoscopic surgery simulation, preoperative simulation is possible before laparoscopic surgery. We are also conducting simulation of laparoscopic surgery for rectal surgery and simulation of laparoscopic surgery for rectal surgery.
surgerySimulation.imageDescription2: Simulation of laparoscopic surgery for rectal surgery

humanInteraction.title: Exploration of the mechanisms of human vision, thinking, and behavior
humanInteraction.content: By using virtual reality (virtual world realization technology), we are trying to apply virtual reality technology to medical applications. We have developed a virtual reality system that can be completely immersed in the human body, and it has been featured in news stations and science channels.
humanInteraction.imageDescription1: Virtual reality system that can be completely immersed in the human body

method.title: Access Method
method.toNagoya-detail: Subway Higashiyama Line Nagoya Station → Motoyama Station (Transfer) → Nagoya University Station 3rd Exit (Transfer included, about 23 minutes)
method.toKanayama-detail: Subway Meijo Line Left → Nagoya University Station (about 25 minutes)
method.toCentrair-detail: Meitetsu Chubu International Airport Station → (Limited Express or Mue Sky is convenient) → Meitetsu Kanayama Station Subway → Meijo Line counterclockwise → Nagoya University Station (approx. 1 hour)
method.subway: Subway Nagoya University Station, Bus Stop Nagoya University Front
method.subway-detail: IB Electronic Information Building South Building 4F (1 minute walk)
